wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Kafkasder-panel non-profit association management system. Explain its purpose as a professional platform for aid associations, foundations, and NGOs with modules for beneficiary management, donation tracking, scholarship administration, financial reporting, and organizational workflows. Document the architecture as a full-stack Next.js 16 and Convex application with real-time capabilities. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Provide practical examples demonstrating common use cases like managing beneficiaries, processing donations, and generating reports. Document the relationship between frontend components, API routes, and Convex backend functions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Hierarchy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the frontend component hierarchy in Kafkasder-panel. Explain the organization of reusable UI components in the components directory, including atomic design principles applied across ui, forms, and feature-specific subdirectories. Document the structure of layout components like PageLayout.tsx and their role in maintaining consistent UI across pages. Describe how higher-order components such as form wizards and data tables are composed from base UI primitives. Include examples from BeneficiaryFormWizard.tsx and KanbanBoard.tsx to illustrate component composition patterns. Address accessibility implementation in form fields and data tables, theming via Tailwind CSS, and responsive design considerations. Provide guidance on creating new components following existing conventions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Convex Backend Functions
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Convex backend functions in Kafkasder-panel. Describe how Convex serves as a real-time serverless backend with automatic data synchronization. Document the three function types: queries (read-only operations), mutations (data modifications), and actions (server-side workflows). Explain how these functions are defined in individual files under the convex/ directory and automatically exposed via the generated API. Detail the security model using Convex's built-in authentication and authorization. Include examples from auth.ts showing getUserByEmail query and updateLastLogin mutation. Address data consistency, transactional guarantees, and real-time subscription mechanisms.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the Authentication API endpoints in the Kafkasder-panel application. Document the POST /api/auth/login endpoint including request body schema (email, password), response formats (success with session token, failure with error codes), and CSRF protection requirements. Detail the GET /api/auth/session endpoint for retrieving current user session data and permissions. Document the POST /api/auth/logout endpoint for session termination. Include information about the development-only /api/auth/dev-login endpoint for testing purposes. Explain authentication flow integration with Convex backend, session management using secure cookies, and role-based access control propagation. Provide examples of successful and failed authentication attempts, error handling strategies, and security considerations including rate limiting and brute force protection.

wiki_catalogs.name: Beneficiaries Data Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the beneficiaries collection in the Kafkasder-panel application. Detail the entity structure with 155 fields including personal, family, health, financial, and social information. Document field definitions, data types, constraints, and validation rules. Explain the indexing strategy with by_tc_no, by_status, and by_city indexes, as well as the search index configuration. Address the normalization concerns of this wide table and document the relationships to related collections like aid_applications, documents, and donations. Include data lifecycle management, retention policies, and performance considerations for querying this large collection.

wiki_catalogs.name: Beneficiary Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Beneficiary Management module. Explain the implementation of beneficiary profiles, applications, dependents, and document management. Document the data model, form validation logic, and UI components used for creating and editing beneficiary records. Include examples from src/app/(dashboard)/yardim pages and convex/beneficiaries.ts functions. Describe workflows for adding, updating, and viewing beneficiary details. Address integration with document storage, dependent tracking, and audit logging. Cover common issues such as data sanitization, validation errors, and performance optimization when handling large beneficiary datasets.

wiki_catalogs.name: Convex Queries
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Convex queries in Kafkasder-panel. Explain that queries are read-only functions used to retrieve data from the Convex database, executed in a consistent snapshot and automatically synchronized in real time to subscribed clients. Document how queries are defined using `defineQuery` and registered in individual module files (e.g., `getUserByEmail` in auth.ts). Include examples from auth.ts and users.ts demonstrating parameter validation with Zod and integration with the data model. Describe how queries are accessed client-side via the generated Convex API (`api.queries.*`). Address performance considerations such as indexing strategies in schema.ts, query optimization, and caching behavior. Explain real-time subscription mechanics and how React components use Convex hooks like `useQuery` for reactive updates.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication & Authorization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the authentication and authorization system in Kafkasder-panel. Thoroughly explain the email/password login implementation, session management using NextAuth, and role-based access control (RBAC) with user permissions. Document the flow from login request to session creation, including how JWT tokens are handled and stored. Explain the implementation of the authStore for client-side authentication state management. Include concrete examples from the codebase such as the getUserByEmail and getCurrentUser Convex queries, and the login API route handler. Address security considerations like password hashing (bcrypt), session timeout settings, and protection against common vulnerabilities. Provide configuration options for authentication settings and describe integration points with other system components.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API Routes
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the Authentication API Routes in Kafkasder-panel. Document each endpoint: POST /api/auth/login (handles user login with CSRF protection, password verification, and session cookie creation), POST /api/auth/logout (clears session cookie), GET /api/auth/session (retrieves current session), and POST /api/auth/dev-login (development-only login bypass). For each route, specify HTTP method, request/response schema, authentication requirements, and error codes. Explain the integration with Convex auth functions and session management using HttpOnly cookies. Detail CSRF token validation via csrf.ts and rate limiting using authRateLimit. Include security considerations: secure cookie flags, brute-force protection, and development vs production behavior differences. Provide code examples for client-side authentication flow and error handling.

wiki_catalogs.name: Client-Server Communication Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the client-server communication flow in Kafkasder-panel. Explain how React components initiate API requests through Next.js API routes, including the use of fetch in client components and the role of server-side API route handlers. Detail the request lifecycle from UI interaction to API route invocation, covering authentication headers, CSRF token inclusion, and request payload formatting. Include concrete examples from the login flow where the frontend calls /api/auth/login with email and password. Document error handling patterns for network failures and validation errors, and explain how responses are processed in the frontend. Address common issues such as CORS configuration, authentication token persistence, and rate limiting responses.

wiki_catalogs.name: Session Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the session management system in Kafkasder-panel. Explain how user sessions are created during login with the auth-session cookie containing user ID, session ID, and expiration timestamp. Document the implementation of both HttpOnly server-side cookies and client-side localStorage persistence for improved UX. Describe the session validation process in getCurrentUserId that parses and verifies the session cookie, checks expiration, and returns the user ID. Detail the session lifecycle including creation, validation, and cleanup during logout. Include examples of secure cookie configuration (HttpOnly, Secure, SameSite=strict) and how the rememberMe flag affects session duration (24 hours vs 30 days). Explain the relationship between server-side session state and client-side Zustand store synchronization.

wiki_catalogs.name: CSRF Protection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the CSRF protection mechanism in Kafkasder-panel. Explain the implementation of cryptographically secure token generation using randomBytes with 32-character length. Detail the token flow: generation during authentication, storage in HttpOnly cookies, and transmission via 'x-csrf-token' header for state-changing requests (POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE). Document the constant-time string comparison algorithm that prevents timing attacks during validation. Describe the client-side fetchWithCsrf wrapper that automatically injects tokens, and the server-side verification in auth-utils.ts. Include integration points with authentication endpoints and the /api/csrf endpoint for token retrieval. Provide examples of proper usage in forms and API calls, and explain error handling for invalid or missing tokens.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Donation Fields
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the core donation fields in the Kafkasder-panel application. Detail the fundamental fields that apply to all donation types including donor_name, donor_phone, donor_email, amount, currency, donation_type, payment_method, donation_purpose, notes, receipt_number, receipt_file_id, and status. Explain the purpose and constraints of each field, with examples from actual donation records. Document the validation rules and business logic associated with these fields, particularly around required fields and data integrity. Include examples of how these fields are used in both standard donations and Kumbara collections, highlighting their universal applicability across donation types.

wiki_catalogs.name: Beneficiary Profiles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Beneficiary Profiles feature. Explain the implementation of creating, viewing, editing, and deleting beneficiary profiles. Document the data model structure from convex/schema.ts, form validation logic in src/lib/validations/beneficiary.ts, and the UI components used in src/components/forms/BeneficiaryForm.tsx. Include examples from the API routes in src/app/api/beneficiaries/ that handle CRUD operations. Describe workflows for adding new beneficiaries, updating existing records, and handling soft deletes. Address integration with authentication, audit logging, and error handling. Cover common issues such as validation errors, duplicate TC numbers, and performance optimization when listing large datasets.

wiki_catalogs.name: Donation Tracking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Donation Tracking sub-module. Explain the implementation of creating, editing, and viewing individual donations through the DonationForm component and donations.ts Convex functions. Document the data model for donations including donor information, amounts, payment methods, and status transitions. Include examples of form validation using Zod, handling one-time and recurring donations, and integration with user authentication for audit trails. Describe how donation records are synchronized across the UI using Convex real-time subscriptions and how they integrate with financial reporting and audit logs. Address common issues such as duplicate entries, data reconciliation, and handling failed transactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Beneficiary Information
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the core beneficiary information in the Kafkasder-panel application. Detail the essential fields including personal identifiers (id, firstName, lastName), contact information (mobilePhone, email), and status tracking (status, createdAt, updatedAt). Explain the indexing strategy with the by_tc_no index for Turkish ID number lookups and the by_status index for status-based filtering. Include examples of how this data is used in the BeneficiaryForm and BeneficiaryFormWizard components for data entry and validation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Scholarship Entity
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Scholarship entity in the Kafkasder-panel application. Document the data validation rules and business logic for scholarship management, including the indexing strategy with by_category, by_is_active, and by_application_dates indices. wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Income and Expense Tracking sub-feature. wiki_catalogs.name: Internal Messaging

wiki_catalogs.name: CSRF Protection
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for CSRF protection mechanism in Kafkasder-panel. Thoroughly explain the implementation of the generateCsrfToken and validateCsrfToken functions, including the use of cryptographically secure random bytes and constant-time comparison to prevent timing attacks. Document how the CSRF token is generated and stored in a non-HttpOnly cookie via the /api/csrf endpoint, allowing client-side access while maintaining security. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing token generation, header validation, and integration with form submissions. Explain the security rationale behind using strict SameSite policies and secure flags in production. Address common vulnerabilities such as CSRF token leakage and provide best practices for client-side token usage in API requests.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Profiles

Detail the form validation rules, password generation functionality, and UI components used for profile management. Include examples of creating a new user, editing existing profiles, and handling form submissions. Address common issues like email uniqueness validation, role assignment, and profile update workflows. Discuss the integration between the frontend form and backend user creation/update operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Login Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the login flow in Kafkasder-panel. Thoroughly explain the step-by-step process from user input in the CorporateLoginForm to successful authentication. Document the client-side validation, CSRF token acquisition, and API request to /api/auth/login. Explain how the login credentials are validated against the Convex database using the getUserByEmail query, and how password verification is handled via bcrypt in the Next.js API route. Detail the session creation process, including HttpOnly cookie generation, CSRF token setup, and localStorage persistence for Zustand store hydration. Include concrete examples from the codebase such as the handleSubmit method in CorporateLoginForm, the POST handler in login/route.ts, and the login action in authStore. Address security considerations like rate limiting, input sanitization, and protection against brute force attacks through maxLoginAttempts configuration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Rate Limiting Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for rate limiting configuration in Kafkasder-panel. Explain the RATE_LIMIT_CONFIGS array and its pattern-based endpoint matching system that applies different rate limit profiles based on URL patterns. Document the configuration structure including pattern, description, category, and rateLimitFunction properties. Detail how environment variables (RATE_LIMIT_DEFAULT_MAX, RATE_LIMIT_DEFAULT_WINDOW, RATE_LIMIT_PREMIUM_MULTIPLIER) control default behavior and allow runtime customization. Provide examples from the codebase showing how specific endpoints like authentication routes receive stricter limits while read-only APIs have more generous allowances. Explain the validation function that detects duplicate patterns and missing properties in configurations. Include guidance on adding new rate limit rules and testing configuration integrity.

wiki_catalogs.name: HTML Sanitization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for HTML sanitization in Kafkasder-panel. Thoroughly explain the implementation of both async and synchronous HTML sanitization using DOMPurify, including the allowed tags (p, br, strong, em, u, h1-h6) and attributes. Document the async sanitizeHtmlAsync function that safely removes XSS threats while preserving permitted HTML structure, and contrast it with the synchronous sanitizeHtml function used for build-time compatibility. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how script tags, event handlers (onclick), and dangerous attributes are stripped. Address the lazy loading mechanism for DOMPurify to avoid build-time issues, and explain the security implications of allowing specific HTML tags in user-generated content. Provide guidance on when to use async vs sync versions based on execution context.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of Kafkasder-panel. Explain the frontend technologies: Next.js 16, React 19, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, and Framer Motion. Document the backend technologies: Convex real-time database and Next.js API Routes. Describe the state management solutions: Zustand and TanStack Query. Explain the security features: CSRF protection, rate limiting, and Sentry integration. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Provide practical examples of how these technologies work together in the application. Document the rationale behind technology choices and their specific versions.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for the state management architecture in Kafkasder-panel. Detail the use of Zustand for global state management, focusing on authStore.ts for authentication state persistence. Explain the integration of TanStack Query (via Convex client) for server state synchronization, including caching strategies using useApiCache and persistent-cache. Document the separation between client state (Zustand) and server state (Convex queries), and how they interact in components. Include examples of form state management in BeneficiaryForm.tsx and data synchronization in Dashboard pages. Address error handling, loading states, and optimistic updates. Provide best practices for managing complex state interactions and avoiding common pitfalls like stale data or memory leaks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Next.js API Routes
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Next.js API Routes in Kafkasder-panel. Explain how these routes serve as the interface layer between the frontend and Convex backend. Document the request flow: API route receives HTTP request, validates input, calls Convex functions via convexHttp client, and returns JSON response. Detail authentication handling in the login route including CSRF protection, session cookie management, and password verification. Explain rate limiting implementation using authRateLimit wrapper. Describe the API client abstraction in convex-api-client.ts that provides caching and error handling. Include security considerations like HttpOnly cookies, secure flags, and input validation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Donation Management

wiki_catalogs.name: Convex Mutations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Convex mutations in Kafkasder-panel. Define mutations as write operations that modify data within the Convex database, executed atomically with ACID guarantees. Document their implementation using `defineMutation`, including examples like `updateLastLogin` in auth.ts and `createBeneficiary` in beneficiaries.ts. Explain how mutations are validated using Zod schemas and secured via Convex's authorization model. Detail the client-side invocation pattern using `api.mutations.*` and React hooks like `useMutation`. Cover error handling, transactional integrity, and interaction with indexes defined in schema.ts. Provide practical examples of form submissions triggering mutations and describe best practices for optimistic updates and loading states in the UI.

wiki_catalogs.name: Audit Logging

Address performance considerations for high-volume logging and storage optimization strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Server-Convex Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the server-Convex integration pattern in Kafkasder-panel. Explain how Next.js API routes use the ConvexHttpClient to call Convex query and mutation functions, using the login flow as a primary example where api.auth.getUserByEmail is called. Detail the lazy initialization pattern in server.ts that prevents build-time errors by creating the Convex client only when needed. Cover common issues such as failed uploads, access control for sensitive documents, and integration with external document verification services.

wiki_catalogs.name: Contact Information and Address

Explain the indexing strategy with the by_city index for location-based filtering and reporting. Include information on how this data is used for communication, field visits, and geographic analysis of beneficiary distribution. Address data validation for phone numbers and email addresses, and explain how address data supports the organization's operational planning.

wiki_catalogs.name: Scholarship Enumeration Types
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the enumeration types used in the scholarship system of the Kafkasder-panel application. Document the ApplicationStatus enum with values DRAFT, SUBMITTED, UNDER_REVIEW, APPROVED, REJECTED, WAITLIST, WITHDRAWN, and CANCELLED. Explain the PaymentStatus enum with values PENDING, PROCESSING, PAID, FAILED, and SUSPENDED. Describe how these enums are used throughout the application for data consistency, validation, and user interface rendering. Include information about the StudentStatus, EducationLevel, and OrphanStatus enums that support the scholarship management system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Meeting Decisions

Document the relationship between decisions and their parent meetings through the meeting_id field. Include examples of querying decisions by status, owner, or meeting context. Describe the indexing strategy for efficient data retrieval and the business rules governing decision lifecycle. Cover integration with action items, notification systems, and audit logging. Address common issues like maintaining decision history, handling status transitions, and ensuring data consistency when related meetings are modified or deleted.

wiki_catalogs.name: File Upload Security
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for file upload security measures in Kafkasder-panel. Thoroughly explain the validation of file types against allowed MIME types and extensions, including the prevention of double extensions and path traversal attempts. Document the size limitations (5MB maximum) and filename sanitization that removes special characters. Explain the client-side validation in the FileUpload component and server-side validation through the validateFile function. Include the implementation of basic malware scanning that detects executable file signatures (MZ, ELF headers). Address common vulnerabilities such as malicious file uploads, content-type spoofing, and storage-based attacks. Provide configuration options for allowed file types and sizes, and describe the user feedback mechanisms for upload errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Two-Factor Authentication
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) system. Explain the implementation of 2FA enrollment, verification, and management using TOTP and backup codes. Document the backend functions for enabling/disabling 2FA, verifying codes, and managing trusted devices. Detail the security event logging for 2FA activities and the database schema for storing 2FA settings. Include examples of the 2FA enrollment flow, login with 2FA verification, and recovery using backup codes. Address common issues like backup code regeneration, trusted device management, and handling lost 2FA devices. Discuss the integration between the 2FA backend functions and the user management interface for configuring 2FA settings.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the backend architecture of Kafkasder-panel. Describe the high-level design using Convex as a real-time serverless backend with Next.js API Routes as the interface layer. Document the Convex function types: queries, mutations, and actions, and their roles in data access and business logic. Explain the data flow from API routes to Convex functions and back to clients. Describe the authentication flow and security mechanisms including CSRF protection and rate limiting. Include system context diagrams and component breakdowns. Address cross-cutting concerns like error handling, logging, and monitoring with Sentry.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Fetching and Synchronization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for data fetching and synchronization mechanisms in Kafkasder-panel. Explain the integration between Next.js server components and Convex's real-time database through the Convex client. Document the use of server-side data loading in page components and client-side subscriptions for real-time updates. Describe the API abstraction layer in convex-api-client.ts that standardizes interactions with Convex queries and mutations. Illustrate data flow patterns from Convex functions to UI components, including error handling and loading states. Address performance optimization through query deduplication, caching strategies, and selective revalidation. Provide examples from donation and beneficiary pages showing both static and dynamic data loading patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Mechanisms
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the security mechanisms in Kafkasder-panel. Document the multi-layered security approach: CSRF protection using token-based validation, rate limiting to prevent brute force attacks, secure session management with HttpOnly cookies, and input validation. Explain the CSRF implementation using cryptographically secure tokens stored in cookies and validated on state-changing requests. Detail the rate limiting strategy using Redis-backed counters to limit authentication attempts. Describe the security audit logging in security_events collection that tracks login attempts, permission denials, and suspicious activities. wiki_catalogs.name: Task Management API

wiki_catalogs.name: Real-Time Data Synchronization

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Dernek Ynetim Sistemi

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
The project is a modern non-profit association management system built with Next.js 16 and Convex, designed to streamline operations for charitable organizations. The system provides comprehensive tools for managing beneficiaries, donations, scholarships, financial records, and organizational workflows.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Provide a centralized platform for non-profit organizations to manage their operations
- Streamline beneficiary management and aid distribution processes
- Facilitate donation tracking and financial reporting
- Enable efficient communication and collaboration among staff members
- Ensure data security and compliance with privacy regulations

### Target Audience
The primary users of this system are non-profit organizations, charities, and associations that need to manage beneficiaries, donations, and organizational operations. The system is designed for administrative staff, managers, and executives within these organizations.

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The application follows a modern full-stack architecture with a Next.js frontend and Convex backend. The system is organized into several key components:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client] --> B[API Layer]
    B --> C[Business Logic]
    C --> D[Data Access]
    D --> E[(Convex Database)]
    F[Authentication] --> B
    G[Analytics] --> B
    H[Error Tracking] --> B
```

### Design Patterns
The project implements several modern design patterns:
- **Provider Pattern**: Used for state management with React Context and Zustand
- **Repository Pattern**: Implemented through Convex queries and mutations
- **Middleware Pattern**: Applied for authentication, rate limiting, and CSRF protection
- **Observer Pattern**: Utilized with React Query for data synchronization

### System Relationships
The architecture demonstrates a clear separation of concerns with well-defined boundaries between components. The frontend communicates with the backend through API routes, while Convex serves as both the database and serverless function platform.

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `src/app/page.tsx`: Main application entry point
- `src/app/layout.tsx`: Root layout component
- `src/app/providers.tsx`: Provider component for global state and services

### Core Modules
- `convex/schema.ts`: Data model definition
- `src/lib/convex/client.ts`: Convex client configuration
- `src/stores/authStore.ts`: Authentication state management
- `src/lib/auth/get-user.ts`: User authentication utilities

### Configuration Approach
- `next.config.ts`: Next.js configuration with performance optimizations
- `tailwind.config.js`: Tailwind CSS configuration
- `sentry.client.config.ts` and `sentry.server.config.ts`: Error tracking configuration

### External Dependencies
- `package.json`: Project dependencies including Next.js, React, Convex, and various UI libraries

### Integration Points
- `src/app/api/auth/login/route.ts`: Authentication endpoint
- `src/app/api/auth/session/route.ts`: Session management endpoint
- `src/app/api/auth/logout/route.ts`: Logout endpoint

### Component Relationship Diagram
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[App Component] --> B[Providers]
    B --> C[Auth Store]
    B --> D[Query Client]
    B --> E[Convex Provider]
    A --> F[Layout]
    F --> G[Dashboard Pages]
    G --> H[Beneficiary Management]
    G --> I[Donation Tracking]
    G --> J[Scholarship Management]
    G --> K[Financial Dashboard]
    H --> L[API Routes]
    I --> L
    J --> L
    K --> L
    L --> M[Convex Backend]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
The system provides comprehensive functionality for non-profit management, including:
- Beneficiary management with detailed profiles and family information
- Donation tracking with support for Kumbara (money box) collections
- Scholarship application and management
- Financial record keeping and reporting
- Task and meeting management
- User authentication and role-based access control

### Implementation Highlights
- **Authentication System**: Implements secure authentication with session management, CSRF protection, and rate limiting
- **State Management**: Uses Zustand with persistence for client-side state
- **Data Access**: Leverages Convex for real-time data synchronization
- **Security**: Includes comprehensive security headers, input validation, and error handling

### Feature Architecture Diagram
```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Login
    Login --> Dashboard: Successful authentication
    Dashboard --> Beneficiaries: Navigate to beneficiaries
    Dashboard --> Donations: Navigate to donations
    Dashboard --> Scholarships: Navigate to scholarships
    Dashboard --> Finance: Navigate to financial dashboard
    Beneficiaries --> Edit: Edit beneficiary
    Donations --> Add: Add donation
    Scholarships --> Apply: Apply for scholarship
    Finance --> Report: Generate report
    Edit --> Save: Save changes
    Add --> Confirm: Confirm donation
    Apply --> Submit: Submit application
    Report --> Export: Export report
    Save --> Dashboard: Return to dashboard
    Confirm --> Dashboard: Return to dashboard
    Submit --> Dashboard: Return to dashboard
    Export --> Dashboard: Return to dashboard
```

Sources:

- [next.config.ts](c:\Users\isaha\Kafkasder-panel\next.config.ts)
- [layout.tsx](c:\Users\isaha\Kafkasder-panel\src\app\layout.tsx)
- [providers.tsx](c:\Users\isaha\Kafkasder-panel\src\app\providers.tsx)
- [client.ts](c:\Users\isaha\Kafkasder-panel\src\lib\convex\client.ts)
- [authStore.ts](c:\Users\isaha\Kafkasder-panel\src\stores\authStore.ts)
- [get-user.ts](c:\Users\isaha\Kafkasder-panel\src\lib\auth\get-user.ts)
- [schema.ts](c:\Users\isaha\Kafkasder-panel\convex\schema.ts)
- [auth.ts](c:\Users\isaha\Kafkasder-panel\src\types\auth.ts)
- [permissions.ts](c:\Users\isaha\Kafkasder-panel\src\types\permissions.ts)
- [login/route.ts](c:\Users\isaha\Kafkasder-panel\src\app\api\auth\login\route.ts)

</blog>
